utterances: Most - richistan is much more diverse than the wealthy of old.
So in other words, in terms of gender it's probably about 60 percent male, 40 percent women in terms of self-made or people who made their money.
They tend to be married with kids, two and a half kids on average.
They tend to be young during their 40s and 50s.
And as I said before, they tend to be self-made.
They didn't inherit their money.
They started their own companies.
They work very hard for what they got and they want to spend it.
They want to enjoy their money.
Thanks very much, Rob.
Thank you very much.
And indeed spending, there is an - keeping up with the Jones, that's one thing.
Keeping up with the Gates that's more difficult.
Yeah, I take the example of yachts.
Not too long ago, let's say five or seven years ago, a 100-foot yacht was a pretty big deal.
I spoke to a Texas yacht owner in Florida who said, you know, when I launched my yacht, it was a 100 feet.
It was a big deal.
We had a party.
We had a christening.
He would go down to the Bahamas and the Korean - Caribbean and it was a big deal.
And we were sitting on his boat next to boats that were two and three times bigger.
He said, now, he said, my 100-foot boat is like a dingy compared to these other boats.
And I was thinking at what other time in history would somebody called their 100-foot yacht a dingy?
We're talking…
Today, we have boats that are 400 feet and even 500 feet long.
We're talking with Robert Frank about his new read book ""Richistan: A Journey Through the American Wealth Boom and the Lives of the New Rich."" You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And in fact, you draw some distinctions between old money and new money.
Old, you said, was characterized by modesty, tradition, public service, charity, sophisticated leisure.
New has the middle class ethic, self-made fortunes, big spenders, younger, richer and harder working.
I went down to Palm Beach and the whole black tie-ball scene in Palm Beach to me was a good Petrie dish or metaphor for what's happening with new and old money.
And there was a ball down there called the Red Cross Ball, which had been founded by Marjorie Merriweather Post and was the Blue Blood occasion every single year in Palm Beach.
Well, two years ago, it was taken over by a new (unintelligible) named Simon Fireman.
He essentially bought rights to the ball, took it over, and the entire Blue Blood Society of Palm Beach boycotted it.
It was a nightmare.
But this is happening in Greenwich, it's happening in New York - anywhere where there's old money.
New money is completely eclipsing the old money both in terms of its wealth and its social stature.
Speaking about that Red Cross Ball, there's a great quote in your book at somebody saying, last year was bad enough, they have people from Boca(ph).
This year, they have people from Delray.
Can you imagine?
Yeah, and you couldn't see sneer on the woman's face as she said that.
It was just appalling that anyone from outside of the island of Palm Beach would be accepted at that ball.
Liz(ph) in Hercules, California emails: What fascinates me about the rich is the salespeople who have to cater to them.
My son was interested in cars, so I took him to a Jaguar dealership just so he could measure up the stats and the design.
The salesperson when we entered stared at me then at my son who looks past my shoulder to what car I had drove up in.
It happened to be a rental.
We were visiting another state.
The salesman turned up his nose and asked if we live in the area.
With great satisfaction, I said, no, we're visiting our second home.
He seemed to relax a bit but I still felt sorry for him.
This administration has certainly been in overdrive in terms of issuing major regulations that have compliance costs of more than $100 million per year.

And so it will be our job to really prioritize which - regulations where their costs far exceed any kind of benefit and do, you know, which ones are most harmful to our economy and make American workers less competitive.
In this latest jobs report - one of the best we've seen in quite some time.
How do you account for that?
You know, defining and figuring out who is wealthy today based on their clothes, based on their haircut, based on their manners is impossible.
There's guy I talked to named Tim Blix(ph).
He's a billionaire.
He goes in to a shop with his son to buy a suit for his son's graduation, and Tim never wears a suit.
In fact, most of the time, he's in a Hawaiian shirt and beat up stained shorts and sandals.
They go into the store and they essentially get kicked out of the store.
And - so here's a billionaire getting kicked out of a suit store.
And so, he said, he got into his convertible Rolls Royce and waved to the guy as he drove by.
But today, those old status signifiers of what you're wearing, how you speak, what your mannerisms are, those no longer hold true.
It's very hard to tell who's wealthy.
So those sales people today, I'm surprise at that, because today's salespeople really have to just assume that anyone who comes in could be a billionaire.
Let's get one last caller.
This is Sarah(ph).
Sarah is with us from Syracuse, New York.
Yes.
Hi.
I'm a professor of public policy and I wanted to ask you question about the role of policy in creating the super wealthy.

The conversation so far makes it sound as though these are self-made people, but in reality a lot of the tax laws and other kinds of laws that the Senate or - and the Congress is passing and President Bush has enacted have created this class of people.
Robert Frank writes a lot about that.
Robert?
That's the sort of classic Kevin Phillips argument.

He wrote a book called ""Wealth and Democracy"" where he says that most wealth today is the result of inheritance or government policy that the taxes and government shifts of wealth really create the wealth.

I do give some credence to that argument and there are some evidence of that, but if you really drill down and interview today's wealthy, I didn't see much evidence that tax policy played a huge role, obviously, it plays a role or that government contracts or government decisions play a huge role in wealth.

So much of today's wealth is truly independent of government and while a government helps as a catalyst for some of that, I think if you change tax policy, you're still going to see huge increases in wealth and wealth disparity in coming years.
All right.
Sarah…
Hello.
…I know you will probably disagree, but frankly, we're out of time so…
Okay.
…we'll reserve that for another show.
Thank you.
But thanks very much for the call.
And Robert Frank, thanks very much for your time.
Thanks for having me.
And we appreciate the tour - guided tour.

The book is ""Richistan: A Journey Through the American Wealth Boom and the Lives of the New Rich."" Robert Frank is a special senior writer for the Wall Street Journal where he writes a blog and a column called the Wealth Report.
the treasure of old letters found stashed in a Swiss laundry room.
Five hundred years of history are up for sale, including a love letter from Napoleon and a letter of condolences written by John Donne in 1624.
Plus, the letters in our inbox - your emails.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
The Department of Homeland Security issued a regulation today.
It restricts the kinds of archaeological materials that can be imported from Egypt - not a big deal unless you're a collector or work for a museum.
But it underscores a point.
Lots of federal regulations take effect every day.
In the waning days of a presidential administration, there's usually an uptick.
And that's been the case this year.
It doesn't please Republicans.
But it gives hope to people who want new policies in place before a President Trump is in the White House.
NPR's Brian Naylor reports.
They're called midnight regulations, implying they're issued in the dark of night or at the last hour of an outgoing administration.
Susan Dudley, director of the Regulatory Studies Center at George Washington University, defines them more broadly.
I tend to think of true midnight regulations as those issued after the election - so during that three months between Election Day and Inauguration Day.
And, historically, across administrations, regardless of party, we tend to see an uptick in regulatory activity in that window.
The center says there are now some 340 significant regulations in the works that fit that description, 59 of which are deemed economically significant.
That means they're expected to have an impact on the economy of $100 million or more.
White House spokesman Josh Earnest pushes back against the notion that the Obama administration is working overtime to issue new regulations.
The regulatory work that's being done in this administration is not going to be characterized by a last-minute rush on the way out the door.
I think what it will be characterized by is a continuous and persistent effort to complete the work that's already been started.
David Goldston of the Natural Resources Defense Council says his group hopes some environmental regulations are among those finalized between now and Inauguration Day.
There are energy-efficiency standards for appliances.
There's the ability to permanently prevent offshore drilling in the Arctic, in the Atlantic.
Those are probably two of the most prominent remaining sets.
Republicans in Congress, meanwhile, are telling the Obama administration not to issue any more regulations.
Republican Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin has sent that message to a number of agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration, the Department of Labor and the EPA.
Lawmakers can overturn regulations issued in the last 60 working days of Congress under the Congressional Review Act.
But such votes take up valuable time in the Senate, which also needs to act on hundreds of Trump-administration nominees and pass a budget.
Brian Naylor, NPR News, Washington.
We'll begin NPR's business news with Amazon protests.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Today, representatives of Amazon's employees in Germany plan to take their fight to the company's headquarters in Seattle.
About 1,000 unionized Amazon workers in Germany are going on strike today in the midst of the crucial holiday season.
They're asking to be paid on a similar scale to the mail order and retail sectors.
Amazon considers these workers logistics workers and say they are well paid by those standards.
Germany is Amazon's biggest market outside of the U.S., generating almost $9 billion in sales last year.
The German workers cause will be taken up outside Amazon's head office in Seattle by several unions, including the Teamsters.
Here's how some are describing the latest U.S.
employment numbers - not good, pretty bad, far below expectations.
That was the reaction when the Labor Department announced just 38,000 jobs were created last month.
So is this the beginning of a trend or is it an aberration?
NPR economics correspondent John Ystdie reports.
Everyone expected the job growth in May might be a little subdued.
Analysts knew a strike by Verizon workers was going to subtract 35,000 jobs from the total.
But most economists anticipated about 160,000 jobs would be added.
So Diane Swonk of DS Economics says the paltry gains were a body blow.
